title: Quotation of the Day: Afghans Living in Fear as More Become Targets
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 3, 2021.
content: “The only tangible thing that has happened to Afghans under the peace process is that they used to know who their killers are, and now they don’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis chides those traveling abroad to escape coronavirus lockdowns.
description: The pope delivered his weekly address from a Vatican library, because the plaza he usually speaks to has been closed to the public.
content: Pope Francis on Sunday criticized people who traveled abroad during the pandemic “to escape the lockdown,” saying they were ignoring those who were suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Take a moment and cook David Tanis’s January menu: creamy leek and parsnip soup, herbed chicken and spinach meatballs, and a citrus and persimmon salad.
content: Good morning. I’ve been scouting for snowy owls, looking for them at the edge of the salt marsh near the airport, where they come some winters from the Arctic tundra where they nest and breed. It’s stakeout work, using the car as a blind, and sometimes I bring along a sandwich: commodity Bologna, lately, with Swiss cheese, pickles, mayonnaise and mustard, on rye toast. That and a thermos of milky tea leaves me feeling like Bunk on “The Wire,” which is to say great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Shirley Young, Businesswoman and Cultural Diplomat to China, Dies at 85
description: Breaking barriers she rose in the advertising industry before General Motors took her onboard. She later used classical music to forge closer ties between Americans and the Chinese.
content: Shirley Young, a Chinese-American businesswoman who broke barriers in the corporate world before starting a second career as a cultural diplomat, using classical music to bridge the ever-widening divisions between China and the United States, died on Dec. 26. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: To Keep Moving, Download Some Ambition
description: If you need a dose of exercise inspiration, it’s easy to find online or on your phone with these guides and apps.
content: It’s a hibernation season like no other: It’s colder and darker, and you're still inside. Which makes it all the more important (and all the harder) to keep yourself moving. As 2021 begins, here are some ideas to get you out of the house, or at least off the couch for a bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Will You Pay to Stream Comfort Shows? Discovery Is About to Find Out
description: A cable-era way of watching TV comes to streaming with the debut of Discovery+, an on-demand platform with lots of nature shows and cooking programs.
content: When Disney+ made its debut, it served up a “Star Wars” blockbuster, “The Mandalorian.” When AppleTV+ came online, it offered a big-budget original series starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston. Another newcomer to streaming, HBO Max, lured subscribers with a “Wonder Woman” sequel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: As the Virus Spikes, Vaccine Distribution Is One More Hurdle for States
description: Mass vaccination would be a challenge under any circumstances. But doing it during an out-of-control pandemic is straining states, cities and health departments.
content: The coronavirus vaccine may end the pandemic at some point, but for now its slow rollout is straining relations between the federal government and states and cities, and is adding one more huge challenge for overstressed health departments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Exchanged Numbers During a Chance Encounter in the Elevator ’
description: New neighbors, a memorable party and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Julian Assange Faces Ruling on Extradition to U.S.
description: A British judge plans to rule on Monday whether the WikiLeaks founder should be sent to the U.S. to face charges of violating the Espionage Act and hacking government computers.
content: A judge in London plans to rule on Monday whether Britain should extradite Julian Assange to the United States, where the WikiLeaks founder faces charges of conspiring to hack government computers and violating the Espionage Act by obtaining and releasing confidential documents in 2010 and 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 9 Killed in Head-On Crash in Fresno County, Calif., Police Say
description: The 28-year-old driver of an S.U.V. and all eight occupants of a pickup were killed, including seven young people, the California Highway Patrol said.
content: Nine people, including seven people who ranged from 6 to 15 years old, were killed in a fiery head-on crash between an S.U.V. and a pickup truck in Fresno County, Calif., on Friday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: South Carolinians Mock Redesigned Palmetto Tree on Proposed State Flag
description: A proposed new look for the beloved state tree has drawn complaints that it looks like a toilet brush or like one of the palmettos battered by Hurricane Hugo in 1989.
content: The goal was to come up with a standard design for the South Carolina state flag, one that residents could rally around, fly from their porches or proudly display on T-shirts, mugs and hats. But a proposed redesign of the beloved palmetto tree on the flag hasn’t exactly made hearts swell with state pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: This 14-Year-Old Ski Daredevil Is Already a Pro, and Trying Not to Scare His Parents
description: Kai Jones skis way out of bounds. But relentless practice on and off the slopes gives him confidence for tricks ready-made to go viral and emblematic of freeskiing’s growth.
content: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Kai Jones, who at 14 is already a professional adventure skier with the videos to prove it, likes to reminisce about the old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman
title: Draw the Year Ahead
description: A more/less list helps you set your intentions for this new year.
content: Twenty-twenty was a hard year for many people. Drawing is one way to remind yourself of some of the positive things that happened, the things that brought you joy, as well as the stuff you could do without in 2021. An illustrated More/Less list is a relaxed version of the classic New Year’s resolution list, and a way to envision the things you would like more of in your life, and the things you would like to drop. Here’s how to do it:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Happy New Year, Here’s $600
description: The new stimulus bill is here. Brexit finally happened. And the vaccines are coming … slowly.
content: Welcome to 2021. The next few months may not be any easier than the last, but let’s take it one week at a time. Here’s the business and tech news you need to know for the days ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: The homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi were reportedly vandalized.
description: The homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi, political opponents and the two most powerful members of Congress, were reported to have been vandalized, as their standoff continues over a stimulus bill that has been criticized as inadequate by from both the left and right — including President Trump.
content: The homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi, political opponents and the two most powerful members of Congress, were reported to have been vandalized, as their standoff continues over a stimulus bill that has been criticized as inadequate by from both the left and right — including President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Richard Fausset
title: Democrats Rush to Turn Out Black Voters in Georgia, Looking Beyond Atlanta
description: Rallying voters across the state over the weekend, the Democratic challengers, Jon Ossoff and the Rev. Raphael Warnock, tried to encourage election-day turnout on the left.
content: GARDEN CITY, Ga. — Democrats in Georgia raced on Sunday to make their final voter turnout push in the state’s pivotal Senate runoff elections, targeting Black voters in regions far from Atlanta but equally important to Georgia’s emerging Democratic coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Mourns an Immigrant’s Life Cut Short
description: The killing of Agitu Ideo Gudeta, a successful business owner from Ethiopia who raised goats and made cheese, has resonated across the country. The police say a farmhand was responsible.
content: ROME — She was an immigrant who became known as a successful business owner in a remote valley in northern Italy. But most Italians had probably never heard of Agitu Ideo Gudeta until last week, when the Ethiopian-born cheesemaker was found bludgeoned to death in her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Cobra Kai’: Strike First. Strike Hard. Come Back for More.
description: In a group interview, Ralph Macchio, William Zabka and Elisabeth Shue discuss their “Karate Kid” bond and the new, reunion-heavy season of the sequel series, “Cobra Kai.”
content: This interview includes spoilers for the new season of “Cobra Kai.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Take Your Family on a Treasure Hunt With Geocaching
description: A game of hide-and-seek using GPS technology is a joyful distraction for many.
content: If it feels as if you’ve already explored every last nook and cranny of your cramped lockdown life know this: Right under your nose, there’s a hidden world operating entirely out of view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Georgia, Britain, Winter TV: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Toby Levy
title: The Holocaust Stole My Youth. Covid-19 Is Stealing My Last Years.
description: A Holocaust survivor reflects on what it means to survive the pandemic.
content: These days, I’m a little bored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: A Covid-19 Relief Fund Was Only for Black Residents. Then Came the Lawsuits.
description: Oregon earmarked $62 million to explicitly benefit Black individuals and business owners. Now some of the money is in limbo after lawsuits alleging racial discrimination.
content: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Brown
title: Cat Girl? A Kinder, Gentler Superhero Comic
description: Katie the Catsitter wrangles 217 “genius-level smart,” slightly “evil” felines in Colleen AF Venable and Stephanie Yue’s new graphic novel series.
content: KATIE THE CATSITTERWritten by Colleen AF VenableIllustrated by Stephanie Yue
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Armed Attackers Kidnap and Kill 11 Miners in Pakistan
description: Officials said all the victims were ethnic Hazaras, a Shiite minority group that Sunni extremists have often targeted.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Armed men abducted and killed at least 11 coal miners in southwestern Pakistan early Sunday, officials said. All the victims were ethnic Hazaras, a minority Shiite group that has often been the target of Sunni extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Harrell
title: An Unwilling Einstein Who’s Full of Beans
description: Chris Grabenstein’s new series, “The Smartest Kid in the Universe,” follows the suddenly brilliant adventures of a kid and a candy jar.
content: THE SMARTEST KID IN THE UNIVERSEBy Chris Grabenstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ryder Howe
title: Wall Street Eyes Billions in the Colorado’s Water
description: Investor interest in the river could redefine century-old rules for who controls one of the most valuable economic resources in the United States.
content: There is a myth about water in the Western United States, which is that there is not enough of it. But those who deal closely with water will tell you this is false. There is plenty. It is just in the wrong places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Something a Diva May Sing
description: Kathy Wienberg pays tribute in the first Monday puzzle of 2021.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I don’t know about you but, for many reasons, I am happy to close the book on the year 2020. I’m looking forward to a peaceful 2021. “Mundane” comes to mind as a positive adjective, as do the words “kind” and “safe.” May it be so for all of you as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Native Americans Reliant on Hospital Feel Abandoned by U.S. During Pandemic
description: Faced with a budget shortfall, the Indian Health Service reduced a federally funded hospital in New Mexico to a clinic as coronavirus cases continued to rise in the state.
content: The Indian Health Service had a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Inflatable Costume May Be Behind Outbreak at California Hospital
description: An employee at a hospital in San Jose wore an “air-powered” costume on Christmas. Within days, 44 staff members had tested positive for the coronavirus, a spokeswoman said.
content: An air-powered, inflatable costume, worn by a staff member on Christmas to spread holiday cheer, may be to blame for a coronavirus outbreak that infected dozens of workers in a hospital in San Jose, Calif., a hospital spokeswoman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Floyd Little, Star Running Back for Syracuse and Broncos, Dies at 78
description: Gen. Douglas MacArthur urged him to attend West Point, but he became an Orangeman to honor a promise to Ernie Davis.
content: Floyd Little, who followed Jim Brown and Ernie Davis in an extraordinary line of all-American running backs at Syracuse University, each wearing No. 44, and who donned it again when he forged a Hall of Fame career with the Denver Broncos, died on Friday at his home in Henderson, Nev., near Las Vegas. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Former Rep. Max Rose Says He Will Not Run for New York City Mayor
description: Mr. Rose, a Democrat who lost re-election for his House seat in Staten Island, had said a mayoral bid would be an “underdog campaign.”
content: Max Rose, the recently ousted Democratic congressman from Staten Island, will not run for mayor of New York City after all, he announced on Sunday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Fugitive Kills Pastor in Texas Church Shooting, Police Say
description: The pastor of a Methodist church was killed with his own gun by a man sought by the police who had taken shelter in the building, officials said. Three others, including the gunman, were hurt.
content: A police chase on Saturday evening in East Texas culminated in a fatal confrontation on Sunday morning in a church between its pastor and a fugitive who was hiding there, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Katherine Cusumano
title: Gaze at the Night Skies and Unwind With a Yoga Class
description: This week, learn about the history of vaccines, explore Mammoth Hot Springs or learn to code.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Tepper
title: Spend Less, and Smarter, in 2021
description: Last year we were just trying to roll with the punches. Hopefully now we can apply some of those survival skills to our finances.
content: For many people, 2020 was not a year for saving money. Even those who remained employed suddenly found themselves shelling out for unforeseen expenses: A used car because public transport suddenly seemed unsafe. A salary for a pod tutor to help their children with remote learning. Subscriptions to multiple streaming services to make life at home more tolerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Paige Rense, Trendsetting Editor of Architectural Digest, Dies at 91
description: Showcasing the lavish homes of world leaders and celebrities, she and her magazine became powerful forces in interior design.
content: Paige Rense, the influential editor of Architectural Digest who transformed it from a local Los Angeles trade journal into a renowned design publication with global reach, died on Friday at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 4, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Giants Bumble Their Way Into a Victory, but Washington Wins the Division
description: The Giants needed to beat Dallas and receive outside help to win the N.F.C. East. They did their part, but the Eagles lost to Washington Sunday night, ending the Giants’ season.
content: Perhaps it is no surprise that a Giants regular season that began with five successive defeats, one victory in the first eight games and a startling late-season charge into playoff contention would not conclude with a routine, humdrum game. No, this topsy-turvy Giants season deserved to end with gripping drama, slapstick failure and ultimately gratifying perseverance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: A case every six seconds: The mayor of Los Angeles warns of the virus’s rapid spread in households.
description: "What’s happening in L.A. can and will be coming in many communities in America," the mayor warned.
content: The latest surge of the coronavirus in Los Angeles County is infecting a new person every six seconds, Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles said Sunday. And it is accelerating exactly where people are least likely to be on their guard: in private.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: 9 Sisters at Upstate Convent Die as Outbreak Infects 47
description: The deaths at the St. Joseph’s Provincial House outside Albany came as the virus surged in New York.
content: A coronavirus outbreak at a convent near Albany has infected nearly half of its roughly 100 residents, leaving nine sisters dead in December, the convent and local officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: They Seem to Think the Next Four Years Will Be Normal
description: A Beltway school of journalism wants to get back to just-the-facts-ma’am reporting. But how do you cover this Republican Party?
content: The big debates over political journalism in the Trump years were about morality. What began with arguments over whether the media should call something a “lie” or “racist” has now become: How do you cover a Republican Party that votes to overturn an election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: ‘Losing our grip’: In some neighborhoods, the devastation of the pandemic goes far beyond the disease itself.
description: Plenty of numbers can quantify the way the pandemic and the resulting recession have battered the United States: At least 7.8 million people have fallen into poverty, the biggest plunge in six decades; 85 million Americans say they have had trouble paying basic household expenses, including food and rent.
content: Plenty of numbers can quantify the way the pandemic and the resulting recession have battered the United States: At least 7.8 million people have fallen into poverty, the biggest plunge in six decades; 85 million Americans say they have had trouble paying basic household expenses, including food and rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Brandon Thibodeaux
title: ‘A Slap in the Face’: The Pandemic Disrupts Young Oil Careers
description: Students and recent graduates struggle to get hired as the oil industry cuts tens of thousands of jobs, some of which may never come back.
content: HOUSTON — Sabrina Burns, a senior at the University of Texas at Austin, had thought she would be launching a lucrative career in the oil and gas industry when she graduated in a few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Stephanie Saul
title: Trump, in Taped Call, Pressured Georgia Official to ‘Find’ Votes to Overturn Election
description: The president vaguely warned of a “criminal offense” as he pressured Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger in the call, according to an audio recording.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump pressured Georgia’s Republican secretary of state to “find” him enough votes to overturn the presidential election and vaguely threatened him with “a criminal offense” during an hourlong telephone call on Saturday, according to an audio recording of the conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Teachers on TV? Schools Try Creative Strategy to Narrow Digital Divide
description: It’s another way to reach students without internet or computers during the pandemic.
content: Nearly every weekday morning, Valentin Vivar curls up in bed next to his older sister, Araceli, and switches on one of his favorite television shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
title: India Approves Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid-19 Vaccine and 1 Other
description: The approvals, which include a shot developed by Bharat Biotech, an Indian pharmaceutical company, begin a vast campaign to inoculate the hard-hit nation’s 1.3 billion people.
content: NEW DELHI — India said on Sunday that it had approved two coronavirus vaccines, one made by AstraZeneca and Oxford University and the other developed in India, for emergency use, a major step toward halting the spread of the coronavirus in one of the world’s hardest-hit countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Kim Chernin, Who Wrote About Women, Weight and Identity, Dies at 80
description: In a memoir, she also recounted her upbringing as the daughter of Rose Chernin, a Communist organizer convicted of trying to overthrow the government.
content: Kim Chernin, a feminist author and counselor who wrote with compassion about female body dysmorphia and its cultural causes, as well as her own upbringing as the daughter of a fiery Communist organizer jailed for her beliefs, died on Dec. 17 at a hospital in Marin County, Calif. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jets’ Final Loss to Patriots Comes Ahead of Expected Overhaul
description: The Jets lost an early lead to New England and finish with a 2-14 record amid reports that Coach Adam Gase will be fired and as the team decides whether it will retain quarterback Sam Darnold.
content: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Cam Newton saved his best performance this season for what was likely his final game with the New England Patriots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Browns Are In, Ending N.F.L. Playoff Drought
description: Cleveland beat Pittsburgh on Sunday, qualifying for the playoffs for the first time since the 2002 season.
content: Cleveland Browns fans love to revel in their misery. The long list of dud coaches. The unending line of quarterback busts. The team abandoning the city only to return a few years later. And all that losing, including a winless season in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Ratatouille’ Review: What’s Small and Hairy With Big Dreams?
description: What started as a TikTok meme and became a crowdsourced musical could have online lessons to offer for Broadway.
content: As bad as the pandemic has been for plays, it has been even worse for musicals, which are not only intensely collaborative but also inherently unhygienic. The next “A Chorus Line” won’t emerge while everyone is standing six feet apart. No new “Hamilton” can spit its rhymes from behind a wall of masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
title: Georgia Is Getting More Blue. The Senate Races Will Tell How Much.
description: A reliably red state for almost two decades, Georgia no longer resembles its Deep South neighbors. President Trump and Joe Biden head there Monday to help rally the bases.
content: With President Trump touching down in North Georgia on Monday to court white rural voters and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. rallying support from a diverse electorate in Atlanta, the high-stakes Senate runoffs are concluding with a test of how much the politics have shifted in a state that no longer resembles its Deep South neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 3, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 3, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about problems in learning pods misidentified the number of children in a pod in Oakland, Calif. There were four, not six.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Asian-American Voters Can Help Decide Elections. But for Which Party?
description: They surged to the polls in 2020 and could help swing the Georgia Senate runoffs. Activists and experts say it is long past time for both Democrats and Republicans to pursue them.
content: The message Asian-American voters sent in 2020 was clear: Seek us out, listen to what we tell you, and we can help you win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: A Year of Scandals and Self-Questioning for France’s Top Publishers
description: The release of “Consent” put France’s literary establishment under a harsh spotlight. The publishing industry is grappling with a nation that it resembles less and less.
content: PARIS — France’s publishers are usually cloistered in newspapers’ genteel book sections or discussed with near reverence on television literary programs. But for the past 12 months, they have been under the harsh spotlight of muckraking online investigators and of police blotters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Vecsey
title: Because of an Editing Error
description: Blunders, gaffes and terrible math skills, written in permanent ink.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: With Concessions and Deals, China’s Leader Tries to Box Out Biden
description: Xi Jinping has been making trade agreements in Asia and now Europe, hoping to head off the incoming president’s efforts to rally a united front against China.
content: A trade pact with 14 other Asian nations. A pledge to join other countries in reducing carbon emissions to fight global warming. Now, an investment agreement with the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: India greenlights two coronavirus vaccines.
content: The two — one made by AstraZeneca and Oxford University and the other, developed in India by the company Bharat Biotech  — were given the green light on Sunday for emergency use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Brian Urquhart, Troubleshooter for the U.N., Dies at 101
description: He was best known for creating and directing the U.N.’s peacekeeping operations in conflict-filled areas around the world.
content: Brian Urquhart, a troubleshooting British diplomat who joined the United Nations at its birth in 1945 and over the next four decades was a chief aide to five secretaries general while directing peacekeeping operations around the world, died on Saturday at his home in Tyringham, Mass. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omar Hama Saley and Ruth Maclean
title: 100 Civilians Are Reported Dead After Attacks in Niger
description: Gunmen were described as having singled out men and boys in two villages in a region under siege by militants.
content: NIAMEY, Niger — A hundred civilians  were killed in attacks by suspected militants in the West African nation of Niger on Saturday, according to government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to Excerpts From Trump’s Call
description: The president pressured Georgia’s secretary of state to overturn the state’s election results.
content: The president pressured Georgia’s secretary of state to overturn the state’s election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Kevin Quealy
title: 2020 N.F.L. Playoff Picture for Week 17: Mapping All the Scenarios
description: Visualizing all the playoff possibilities.
content: Visualizing all the playoff possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: Sync your calendar with the solar system
description: Never miss an eclipse, a meteor shower, a rocket launch or any other astronomical and space event that's out of this world.
content: Never miss an eclipse, a meteor shower, a rocket launch or any other astronomical and space event that's out of this world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Cuomo Won’t Get Vaccine Until It’s Available for Those Hardest-Hit
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said he would not be vaccinated for Covid-19 until vaccines were widely available for his age group in Black, Latino and poor New York communities.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said he would not be vaccinated for Covid-19 until vaccines were widely available for his age group in Black, Latino and poor New York communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Icy Podcasts to Warm Your Cold, Cold Heart
description: A polar podcast playlist from cold places, full of nonfiction and fiction storytelling set in the snow.
content: As the holiday season retreats and the long slog of the winter months looms, you can fight the mood or embrace it. Here’s a playlist of cold-weather podcasts, some fiction, some nonfiction, all well-told and produced, and all set in the snow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Casting a Wider Net for Elite School Admission
description: Readers discuss an editorial about the latest opportunity to right some public school wrongs in New York City.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Empathy Lesson for Teens Amid a Pandemic
description: A reader writes: “Ask your kids: What can bored privileged teens, with broadband access and computers, do to help others?”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
